content.description: 5 bolts of easy climbing lead up and left to the middle ledge (use long draws).  A hard first move off the ledge is followed by hard sustained climbing and the crux sequence through the last 2 bolts.  Originally graded 12c (which I'll admit was a sandbag) then bumped up to 13a.  Seems to be settling in at 12d, but you be the judge.
content.location:
The 1st route right of

Middle Class Cracker

follows the leftmost of the 3 black streaks on the obvious overhanging headwall (see photo on the Middle Class page).

content.description: Start up easy ground and carefully clip the 1st bolt (or stick clip) then hand traverse the right angling horizontal crack to a stance out right.  Getting from the 1st to the 3rd bolt is the routes crux sequence - powerful with a tough 2nd clip.  Be careful clipping the 3rd bolt, itÂ’s an easy clip from good holds but a bad one to blow.  Stays hard through the 4th bolt and becomes easier as you approach the middle ledge.   From the middle ledge power up a hard move or two to gain the slab and follow it up and right through the white rock and good jugs into the dihedral and the right side of the small roof up high (be careful not to go straight up into Overtime).  Surmount the roof and continue past the last bolt to a mantle finish.
content.location: The middle route of the 3 on the smiley face (see photo on Middle Class page).

content.description:
Climb the first 8 bolts of

Streaky Stylee

and then rather than going right into the dihedral go straight up through a couple of small roofs and the crux bulge finish (the crux climbs to the right of the last 2 bolts, once established on some decent holds traverse left to clip the last bolt and continue left to the chains).  This is the access route to reach the Upper Middle Class Wall (which explains the traverse left at the end).
content.location:
See photo on Middle Class page and the description for

Streaky Stylee

.

content.description: Undercling/layback the small roof at the start and continue up the slab to chains on the left side of the middle ledge.  Short and not super sustained at the grade but great rock and quality climbing.  A bit runout getting to the chains but the climbing gets a lot easier as you get further away from the last bolt (there is a slabby crux right above the last bolt).
content.location: The left route of the 3 on the smiley face (see photo on Middle Class page).

content.description: Middle Class Cracker is a fun little chosseneering adventure up the middle of the Middle Class Wall. Start on the grey streak right of the "smiley face" and climb up a short corner, move up and left over ledges, bushes, and loose blocks towards the obvious, right-leaning crack system higher up. A couple of fun moves gain the corner, and good climbing finishes the route off - rap anchors to the right. Avoid the higher set of bolts (and the loose, block filled chimney). Despite a lot of lichen, bushes, and bird shit, I really enjoyed this climb. It reminded me of photos I've seen of the classic rock climbs on Mt. Yamnuska in Alberta - for whatever that's worth.... Anyway, given the excellent sport climbing on the Triple Tier, it's worth packing a light rack along with your draws, as this route makes a fine warm up or cool down.
content.protection: Single set of cams and stoppers. 4-5 runners useful.
content.location: Middle Class Wall. Begin in the grey corner right of the "smiley face".

content.description:
Start as for

Twinkletoes

but continue up and right after the 1st bolt passing 3 more bolts to a ledge, then veer right past 2 more bolts to the middle ledge.  Finish up the headwall (tricky crux start) past 6 bolts of great, sustained climbing.  It's a real stretch lowering or rapping with a 60m rope - knot the ends or use a 70m.
content.location: The right black streak on the headwall (see photo on Middle Class page).

content.description: Moderate climbing over ledges leads to a couple of hard layback moves at the 4th bolt.  Continue up more easy ground to a bulge finish.
content.location: Currently the rightmost route at Middle Class and the first route encountered on the approach (see photo on Middle Class page).

content.description:
Great rock and a cool 11b-ish sequence lead to middle ledge via 6 bolts.  Above the ledge there are 2 options: either climb a tough boulder problem crux directly through the 2 bolts above (not sure how hard-yet to be done free?), or climb high enough to reach up and clip both bolts and then go back down/reach right to climb the crack for a couple of moves and hand traverse back left to regain the route for a much easier but less direct variation.  The route then converges with

Streaky Stylee

at the prow for a move or two before following bolts back out right to chains.  If not for the weirdness above the middle ledge, this route would get more stars.
content.location: The right route of the 3 on the smiley face (see photo on Middle Class page).

content.description:
Blue Collar Baby is kind of funky but interesting enough with some good sections.

Start stemming in a right-facing dihedral and reach out left to clip the 1st bolt.  Follow the crack out left and pass 3 more bolts (crux) to a ledge and good rest.  Head up and right through steep, blocky terrain to another ledge, then follow the crack past 2 more bolts and yet another ledge out left before climbing the nice prow to the chains.
content.location: Currently this is the leftmost route at Middle Class (see photo on Middle Class page).

content.description:
Climbing this route requires climbing

Overtime

(12b) first or rappelling in from above which is rather adventurous. From the anchor at the top of

Overtime

, head left, then up on runout but easy ground to the 1st bolt and gain the ledge on the left.  Awkwardly move right onto the prow and hug the black streak straight up to the sloping top lip of Upper Middle Class Wall and follow it to chains.  The crux comes about 2/3 of the way up the streak.  Awesome position but hard to get to.
content.protection:
6 bolts to chains from the top of

Overtime

.
content.location:
Starts at the top of

Overtime

and climbs the black streak/prow on the right side of Upper Middle Class Wall.

content.description:
Climb

Overtime

then

Black Eye In The Sky

in one long pitch exercising creative use of long draws.  Probably can't really give it a harder grade than 12b but it most definitely feels harder than it does climbing it in 2 pitches.  A 70m rope is just long enough to lower from the top anchor down to the middle one if you don't want to mess with tagging a line or belaying at the top.
content.location:
See the photo on the Middle Class page and the descriptions for

Overtime

and

Black Eye In The Sky

.
